title: NHS trust shuts children's ward at night and pays PRIVATE ambulances to ferry kids to another hospital
text:
News NHS trust shuts children's ward at night and pays PRIVATE ambulances to ferry kids to another hospital The Doncaster and Bassetlaw Hospitals NHS Trust spends £14,000-a-month moving the children from the 20-bed ward in Worksop to one in Doncaster Share Becky Keith, with her son Zac, who is fighting to keep the Childrens ward of Bassetlaw Hopspital Worksop open (Photo: Daily Mirror) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! An NHS trust is closing a children’s ward at night and paying for private ambulances to take them to a different hospital. 
Parents and politicians branded last month’s move farcical and outrageous. 
The trust spends £14,000 a month moving the kids from the 20-bed ward at Bassetlaw Hospital , Worksop, Notts. 
One team of paediatric paramedics were drafted in from Essex, 150 miles away, and put up in a hotel. 
The closure is the latest incident revealing the fragility of the NHS , which is growing at the slowest rate since 1955. 
Millions of patients face the longest ever waits for casualty care, beds, cancer treatment and operations. 
At least 780 patients spent more than four hours waiting in A&E in January – probably the worst month in 13 years. 
Bassetlaw MP John Mann said of Doncaster and Bassetlaw Hospitals NHS Trust’s decision: “I am demanding that this farcical situation is reversed.” Read More Jeremy Hunt FINALLY admits NHS crisis is 'completely unacceptable' - but refuses to take any blame Ambulance believed to be from Essex parked at Bassetlaw Hopspital Worksop (Photo: Daily Mirror) 
The ward closure meant Brian and Charlotte Button’s one-year-old son Flynn, rushed to hospital with a high temperature, was transferred by ambulance 18 miles from Worksop to Doncaster in the night. 
He later made a full recovery. Brian was shocked the crew was from Essex. 
Becky Keith, whose blind disabled son Zac, four, relies on the ward, called the closure underhand and a nightmare. 
Activist Ellen King said: “This is a disgraceful waste of taxpayers’ money, a prime example of why the NHS is in crisis. It is outrageous ambulances are used as taxis to transfer sick children away from home and their families when we have a perfectly good children’s ward on the doorstep.” Read More Theresa May has 'lost control' of NHS crisis as A&E figures show worst performance EVER 
Idris Griffiths, Chief Officer at NHS Bassetlaw Clinical Commissioning Group said the Doncaster-based ambulance provider “ensures we have a dedicated service at peak times to transfer any child that needs admitting to hospital overnight.” 
David Purdue, from the Trust, said the ward had to close “due to medical and nursing staff vacancies.” THE NHS faces pressures like those in Mid Staffs, said Sir Robert Francis, who led the scandal inquiry. Like us on Facebook
